current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To encourage benchmarking and disclosure of energy
		  information for commercial buildings.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Energy and Natural
			 Resources

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 435(b)(2) of the Energy Independence and Security
			 Act of 2007
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007/s:435/ss:b/p:2

header.#text:
Requirement of
			 benchmarking and disclosure for leasing buildings without energy star
			 labels

text.#text: by striking

quote.#tail:
and all that follows through the period at
			 the end and inserting the following:

text.#text: by striking

quoted-block-continuation-text.#text:
signing
				the contract, the following requirements are met:

text.#text:
The space is
				renovated for all energy efficiency and conservation improvements that would be
				cost effective over the life of the lease, including improvements in lighting,
				windows, and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
				the space is benchmarked under a nationally recognized, online, free
				benchmarking program, with public disclosure, unless the space is a space for
				which owners cannot access whole building utility consumption data, including
				spaces—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007/s:435/ss:b/p:2/sp:B/cl:ii

text.#text: Subject to

that are located in States with privacy
				laws that provide that utilities shall not provide such aggregated information
				to multitenant building owners; and

for which tenants do not provide energy
				consumption information to the commercial building owner in response to a
				request from the building owner.

A Federal agency that is a tenant
				of the space shall provide to the building owner, or authorize the owner to
				obtain from the utility, the energy consumption information of the space for
				the benchmarking and disclosure required by this
				subparagraph.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall complete a study, with opportunity for public
			 comment—

text.#text:
Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of
			 this Act, the

on the impact
			 of—

State and local
			 performance benchmarking and disclosure policies, and any associated building
			 efficiency policies, for commercial and multifamily buildings; and

programs and
			 systems in which utilities provide aggregated information regarding whole
			 building energy consumption and usage information to owners of multitenant
			 commercial, residential, and mixed-use buildings;

that identifies
			 best practice policy approaches studied under subparagraph (A) that have
			 resulted in the greatest improvements in building energy efficiency; and

that
			 considers—

utility
			 practices, programs, and systems that provide aggregated energy consumption
			 information to multitenant building owners, and the impact of public utility
			 commissions and State privacy laws on those practices, programs, and
			 systems;

the treatment of
			 buildings with—

multiple
			 uses;

uses for which
			 baseline information is not available; and

implementation
			 practices, including disclosure methods and phase-in of compliance;

the safety and
			 security of benchmarking tools offered by government agencies, and the
			 resiliency of those tools against cyber-attacks; and

international
			 experiences with regard to building benchmarking and disclosure laws and data
			 aggregation for multitenant buildings.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the results of the study.

text.#text: At the conclusion of the study, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in coordination with other relevant agencies shall, to carry out the
			 purpose described in

text.#text:
Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of
			 this Act and following opportunity for public notice and comment, the

assess existing
			 databases; and

as
			 necessary—

modify and
			 maintain existing databases; or

create and
			 maintain a new database platform.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be for the purpose of storing and making available public
			 energy-related information on commercial and multifamily buildings,
			 including—

text.#text:
The
			 maintenance of existing databases or creation of a new database platform under

buildings that
			 have received energy ratings and certifications; and

energy-related
			 information on buildings provided voluntarily by the owners of the buildings,
			 in an anonymous form, unless the owner provides otherwise.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and with criteria developed
			 following public notice and comment, the Secretary may make competitive awards
			 to utilities, utility regulators, and utility partners to develop and implement
			 effective and promising programs to provide aggregated whole building energy
			 consumption information to multitenant building owners.

text.#text:
Based on the results of the research for the portion of
			 the study described in

shall seek input from stakeholders to
			 maximize the effectiveness of the actions taken under this section.

a report on the progress
